title: Cocktease and whatevs among new words added to Oxford English Dictionary
text:
We didn’t know some of these either (Picture: Metro.co.uk)

As times change and social media spouts an array of new words almost every week, Oxford English Dictionary academics are constantly kept on their toes.

To keep up with the slang that now dominates our every day lives – whether we like it or not – the OED has been updated to include words such as ‘whatevs’, ‘sumfin’, ‘chillax’ and ‘simples’.

But some have criticised the English language’s main source by saying it is allowing too many colloquial terms and that standards are slipping.

Star Wars fans will be happy to know the dictionary has paid somewhat of a homage to George Lucas’ films by including words like ‘Jedi’, ‘lightsaber’, ‘padawan’, ‘The Force’ and ‘Jedi mind trick’.

October’s annual update has also included a fair few words that you probably shouldn’t say around your grandma.

‘Buck naked’, ‘cocktease’ and ‘d***-sucker’ have all made it on the list, along with the more PG-friendly ‘chirpse’ – meaning to flirt.

The OED included the new words in its October update (Picture: Shutterstock)

It seems Donald Trump has something to be proud of too, as ‘fake news’ has made it onto the list after the US president coined the term early in his presidency.

The dictionary has defined the term as the ‘circulation of inaccurate and untrustworthy news stories specifically on social media’.

In keeping with this idea, also added to the list have been the words ‘fakeness’, ‘fakie’ and ‘Jafaican’ – a non-Jamaican person who adopts or identifies with aspects of Jamaican culture in a way regarded as contrived or inauthentic.

To keep up with the modern world of technology, the condition nomophobia has also been included, which is defined as ‘anxiety about not having access to a mobile phone or mobile phone services’.

In a nod to the hit satire show The Thick of It, the word ‘Omnishambles’ has been added to the list, after the British public have regularly used it to describe the chaos of UK politics in the past year.

Some are probably not family-appropriate words (Picture: Getty)

But some are not happy with the latest additions, with one social media user saying the OED had included ‘terrible slang’.

Another said: ‘Well, it’s the simplest solution. If you can’t maintain the level of education in this country, you might as well lower the standards.’

A few new words added to the OED: Angel-faced: Having a face like that of an angel; having a beautiful, sweet, or innocent face Buck naked: Completely without clothing; stark naked Chewy: Chewing gum; a piece of chewing gum. Chillax: To calm down and relax; to take it easy, to chill Chirpse: To flirt with (a person); to make sexual advances towards Chomper: A person who, or an animal or thing which, bites, chews, crushes, or eats something vigorously or greedily Cocktease: A person, typically a woman, who engages (or is regarded as engaging) in cockteasing Easy-breezy: Informal, casual, relaxed, carefree clothing style Fakeness: Appearing fake, deception and insincerity Fakie: Something fake or false: breast, fingernail, eyelash Jafaican: A non-Jamaican person who adopts or identifies with aspects of Jamaican culture in a way regarded as contrived or inauthentic Kapow: Representing the sound of an explosion, a gunshot, a hard punch or blow and a sad noise Jedi: In the fictional universe of the Star Wars films: a member of an order of heroic, skilled warrior monks who are able to harness the mystical power of… Nomophobia: Anxiety about not having access to a mobile phone or mobile phone services Omnishambles: A situation that is comprehensively mismanaged Promposal: An invitation to be someone’s date to a school prom; esp. one which is elaborately staged, filmed, and made available on social media for others to see Simples: Used immediately after a statement giving a solution to a problem to indicate that something is very simple or straightforward to do Slam-dunk: A move in basketball

description: The Oxford English Dictionary has now been updated to include Star Wars, Donald Trump and The Thick of It words.
